importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Publication year of Baek Se-hee's first memoir, 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki', which became a bestseller in South Korea and marked a turning point in mental health discourse.
Year the memoir was translated into English, leading to international popularity and inclusion in the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and a New York Times recommendation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2018 to 2025 represents the rise and global impact of Baek Se-hee's memoirs, especially during the spread of mental health awareness and discussions about depression.

keyTakeAways: Baek Se-hee, a South Korean author, died at age 35 after writing two best-selling memoirs that openly discuss depression and mental health struggles.

Her memoirs, particularly 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki', brought widespread attention to mental health issues in South Korea and globally, normalizing conversations about therapy and emotional suffering.
The book's frank portrayal of dysthymia — a chronic form of depression — helped reduce stigma and encouraged readers to seek mental health support.
Baek donated her organs, saving five lives, highlighting her legacy of compassion and altruism.
She was born in 1990 and studied creative writing at university, later working as a social media director before beginning her writing career after treatment for depression.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Baek Se-hee, a South Korean author born in 1990, died at age 35 after writing two deeply personal memoirs that explore her struggle with dysthymia and depression. Her first memoir, 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki,' became a bestseller in South Korea in 2018 and gained international acclaim after being translated into English in 2022, appearing on the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and receiving a New York Times recommendation. The book's honest portrayal of mental health challenges, including the contrast between suicidal thoughts and simple pleasures like tteokbokki, helped reduce stigma and foster open dialogue about therapy and emotional well-being. Baek also wrote a follow-up memoir in 2019 detailing her ongoing battle with chronic depression. After her death, she donated her heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys, saving five lives, and her legacy continues through both her literary contributions and her compassionate acts. Tributes from her sister and translator underscore her impact as a writer and a person who inspired millions with her honesty and hope.
title: Baek Se-hee, author of bestselling memoir ‘I Want To Die But I Want To Eat Tteokbokki,’ dead at 35
